sub_topic: The possibility of dark matter being composed of axions
message_1: "What is the possible mass range of axions if they constitute a significant amount of the universe's dark matter and what experiments are being conducted to detect their presence?"
message_2:
Axions are hypothetical particles that were initially proposed to solve the strong CP problem in quantum chromodynamics. They are also considered as a potential candidate for dark matter, which makes up about 27% of the universe's total mass-energy content.

The possible mass range of axions is not precisely known, but it is generally believed to be extremely small, in the range of 10^(-6) eV to 10^(-3) eV (micro-electronvolt to milli-electronvolt). This mass range is consistent with the axion being a significant component of the universe's dark matter.

Several experiments are being conducted to detect the presence of axions or to set constraints on their properties. Some of the notable experiments include:

1. ADMX (Axion Dark Matter eXperiment): This experiment uses a high-Q microwave cavity within a strong magnetic field to search for axions converting into photons. It is currently the most sensitive axion search experiment and has set the most stringent limits on the axion-photon coupling for a wide range of axion masses.

2. CAST (CERN Axion Solar Telescope): This experiment aims to detect axions produced in the Sun by converting them into X-ray photons using a strong magnetic field. While it has not yet detected axions, it has set important limits on their properties.

3. IAXO (International Axion Observatory): This is a proposed experiment that will significantly improve upon the sensitivity of CAST. It will use a large-scale helioscope with multiple detection lines to search for solar axions.

4. ABRACADABRA (A Broadband/Resonant Approach to Cosmic Axion Detection with an Amplifying B-field Ring Apparatus): This experiment uses a toroidal magnetic field to search for axion-induced magnetic fields. It aims to probe the unexplored mass range of axions and set new limits on their properties.

5. MADMAX (Magnetized Disc and Mirror Axion eXperiment): This experiment aims to detect axions in the mass range of 40 to 400 ÂµeV by using a series of magnetized discs and a mirror to enhance the axion-to-photon conversion probability.

These experiments, along with other ongoing and proposed projects, are pushing the boundaries of our understanding of axions and their potential role in the universe's dark matter content.
